Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to request, accept or reject an object, action or event
Elaboration: Demonstrating awareness that images represent people or things; for example, pointing to a picture of a tree in a book when an adult communicates ‘tree’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to request, accept or reject an object, action or event
Elaboration: Demonstrating awareness of a few common, simple symbols in the environment; for example, placing rubbish in the bin when noticing a ‘bin’ symbol

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to request, accept or reject an object, action or event
Elaboration: Combining images, letters or words into 2- and some 3-word phrases to request or make comments; for example, communicating ‘It’s my turn.’, ‘I want [object, event or action].’, ‘I like [object, event or action].’ or ‘More drink.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to request, accept or reject an object, action or event
Elaboration: Using 2- to 3-word phrases to reject objects or actions using their preferred communication modality; for example, communicating ‘I am finished.’, ‘Stop now.’ or ‘No more drink.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Turn one page at a time and differentiate between words and images in print and digital texts
Elaboration: Demonstrating awareness of the way books are handled; for example, picking up a book, opening it, then turning it the right way up

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Turn one page at a time and differentiate between words and images in print and digital texts
Elaboration: Exploring books with Braille and/or other tactile content with their hands, one page at a time

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Turn one page at a time and differentiate between words and images in print and digital texts
Elaboration: Looking at books page by page; for example, imitating reading a book from start to finish

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Turn one page at a time and differentiate between words and images in print and digital texts
Elaboration: Pointing to the print while imitating reading a page with both print and pictures

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to express ideas
Elaboration: Making comments about text presented in books or the environment; for example, communicating ‘giraffe tall’ after listening to a story about animals

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to express ideas
Elaboration: Communicating ideas using phrases, for example ‘fast car’ or ‘loud music’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to express ideas
Elaboration: Contributing an idea to the construction of a class story; for example, ‘The car is blue.’ when asked what colour the car should be

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to describe objects
Elaboration: Using their preferred communication modality to describe characteristics of an object using short phrases such as when describing an object as ‘hard’ or ‘soft,’ ‘hot’ or ‘cold’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to describe objects
Elaboration: Identifying the attributes of familiar objects and using their preferred communication modality to describe characteristics of the object, for example ‘Book is small.’ and ‘Ball is round.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify an image or object that represents an idea from a shared text
Elaboration: Responding to questions about the shared text; for example, choosing ‘mouse’ when asked ‘Who is in the house?’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify an image or object that represents an idea from a shared text
Elaboration: Choosing from a selection of images or words; for example, selecting an image of a boat to represent a pirate ship

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use learnt vocabulary related to personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Building their vocabulary; for example, selecting from a bank of related images and/or words such as ‘ocean’, ‘icebergs’, ‘penguins’, ‘polar bears’ when learning about polar environments

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use learnt vocabulary related to personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Demonstrating understanding of frequently used, simple phrases or sentences; for example, moving to the sink after an adult communicates ‘Wash your hands.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use learnt vocabulary related to personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Selecting an image or word to complete class-created cloze sentences using learnt vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify settings, characters and events in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Viewing stories and recounting a setting, character and/or event in texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander storytellers; for example, identifying an eagle representing Bunjil in an illustration from a shared story, or gum trees in photographs of an Australian bush setting

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify settings, characters and events in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Comparing some features of culture that are revealed by settings, characters and events in stories, for example dress, food and daily routines

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Comment on the characters and events in a text
Elaboration: Selecting ‘yes’ or ‘no’ to comment on a character or event, for example when responding to questions such as ‘Did you like the prince in the book?’ and ‘Did you like the way the book ended?’

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Comment on the characters and events in a text
Elaboration: Choosing an image or word from a selection to contribute to a class comment bank about a character or event in a story; for example, contributing the words ‘funny’ or ‘tall’

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Comment on the characters and events in a text
Elaboration: Choosing an image or word to complete the sentence stem, ‘The book was …’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify a character or event in a familiar text
Elaboration: Matching an object, image or symbol of a character or event to the corresponding illustration

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify a character or event in a familiar text
Elaboration: Naming a favourite character from a known text by selecting a representation, such as an object, image or symbol

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify a character or event in a familiar text
Elaboration: Demonstrating awareness that pictures represent people or things; for example, responding ‘beach’ when asked where crabs and seagulls can be found or live

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify a character or event in a familiar text
Elaboration: Re-enacting a story, for example by role-playing a ‘firefighter’ character using props

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar chants, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Using a speech-generating device, voice, signs or actions to participate in a song

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar chants, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Using body percussion to accompany a rhythm in a rhyme, chant or song, for example by tapping knees or stomping feet

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar chants, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Using body parts to replicate actions for repeated parts of a familiar text; for example, waving hands for ‘swish, swish’ or stomping feet for ‘stomp, stomp’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell an event from a preferred or familiar short text
Elaboration: Using their preferred communication modality to identify key information in response to questions about a text, such as ‘Who was there?’ and ‘What happened?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell an event from a preferred or familiar short text
Elaboration: Participating in sequencing activities; for example, ordering symbols to retell key information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their preferred communication modality to initiate a short interaction with others
Elaboration: Engaging in brief back-and-forth communication with a familiar adult or peer using gestures, facial expression, vocalisation, word approximation or signed language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their preferred communication modality to initiate a short interaction with others
Elaboration: Initiating interactions or activities; for example, using a symbol to communicate a desired activity, or taking the hand of a known adult to gain attention or guide them to an activity or object

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to present an idea or object to peers
Elaboration: Participating in show-and-tell, or sharing an experience or artefact from a weekend activity

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short phrases to present an idea or object to peers
Elaboration: Participating in the construction of a morning message by sharing an idea

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name some common letters and their corresponding phonemes
Elaboration: Acquiring sound–letter knowledge through a range of learning experiences, for example multi-sensory methods such as placing letters in sand, pasta or coloured rice; having an adult model writing letters in foam or paint; using letters made from different textures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name some common letters and their corresponding phonemes
Elaboration: Learning phoneme–grapheme representation of a small set of letters at a time, for example ‘s’, ‘a’ and ‘t’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name some common letters and their corresponding phonemes
Elaboration: Demonstrating awareness of a few letters in the environment; for example, finding the first letter of their own name in the environment, such as on labels or schoolwork

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name some common letters and their corresponding phonemes
Elaboration: Finding the letter to match a spoken phoneme

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name some common letters and their corresponding phonemes
Elaboration: Building decoding skills by participating in activities that focus on alphabet knowledge and phonemic awareness; for example, using picture cards and recognising the first letter sound ‘a’ in ‘apple’ (/a/)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name some common letters and their corresponding phonemes
Elaboration: Matching the letter sound to the grapheme; for example, using their preferred communication modality to express the sound to the corresponding letter

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use beginning knowledge of letters and sounds to identify the initial letter sound and grapheme in a word
Elaboration: Participating in activities that teach letter names and sounds

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use beginning knowledge of letters and sounds to identify the initial letter sound and grapheme in a word
Elaboration: Beginning sound isolation; for example, responding when asked ‘What is the first sound in “cat”?’ (/k/)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use beginning knowledge of letters and sounds to identify the initial letter sound and grapheme in a word
Elaboration: Finding an object that matches an initial letter sound and grapheme; for example, doing an environmental walk and collecting objects that match

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify their name when presented in written forms with supporting images
Elaboration: Selecting their own photo and name card from the whiteboard when marking attendance

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify their name when presented in written forms with supporting images
Elaboration: Identifying their name in the school environment; for example, recognising their named personal belongings or schoolwork

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Respond to simple questions about a shared text being listened to and/or viewed
Elaboration: Using their preferred communication modality to provide a response to ‘wh’ questions such as ‘Where does the bird live?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Respond to simple questions about a shared text being listened to and/or viewed
Elaboration: Using illustrations in a text to respond to literal questions; for example, pointing to a picture of a house when asked ‘Where does the person live?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Respond to simple questions about a shared text being listened to and/or viewed
Elaboration: Choosing an image or word from a selection to respond to literal questions such as ‘What colour is the car?’ and ‘How many cars did you see?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Co-create short texts and sequence images
Elaboration: Using sentence stems, such as ‘I like’ or ‘I want’, and adding an idea using 3 or more words together, for example ‘I want the red car.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Co-create short texts and sequence images
Elaboration: Selecting symbols or words and sequencing to contribute to a class text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Co-create short texts and sequence images
Elaboration: Requesting an adult write words next to a picture that has been drawn

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to create letter-like symbols
Elaboration: Using writing tools in purposeful ways to create letter-like symbols

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to create letter-like symbols
Elaboration: Using writing tools more confidently and with more control

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to create letter-like symbols
Elaboration: Including letter-like symbols in their drawing or writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to create letter-like symbols
Elaboration: Labelling their own writing with letter-like shapes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to create letter-like symbols
Elaboration: Beginning to communicate about what they are drawing or writing; for example, taking writing to a teacher and re-reading their sentence
